passage_text: If so, you may wonder how to become a QA engineer. QA engineers, also known as quality assurance engineers, test products to evaluate quality. Frequently, QA engineers test computer software applications and programs. The purpose of a QA engineer is not to determine that a product is “good enough,” but instead to explore all possible problems with the software. QA engineers accomplish this by doing everything a consumer or end user might reasonably do within the confines of the software to pinpoint areas where problems could arise. Some aspiring QA engineers seek recognition as a Certified Software Quality Engineer from the American Society for Quality. Professional experience in a relevant entry-level computer science position is often required to attain a job in this career field.

That experience must be in 1 of the areas of the Certified Quality Engineer's Body of Knowledge, a reference complied by the ASQ. Acceptable areas include management and leadership; product and process design; product and process control; statistical process control; and quality systems.

The field of quality assurance engineering has expanded greatly with the growth in computer ownership.
